awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Robert Fraser is "Harmonic Analysis and Geometric Measure Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK, and the sponsoring scientist is James Wright.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit


The goals for this project were to examine the relationship between Fourier analysis, geometric measure theory, and additive combinatorics.

 

In a joint work with Kyle Hambrook, the first explicit example of a Salem set in Rn is given. The construction is based on a new notion of Diophantine approximation in rings of the form R ⊗Q K for algebraic number fields K.


In a joint work with Jim Wright, a new proof of the Igusa conjecture for two-dimensional exponential sums with polynomial phase is established. This result had previously been established in all dimensions by Cluckers, Mustaţă, and Nguyen. This new proof is based on adapting a real-variable method of Ikromov and Muller to the p-adic setting.


A new framework of landmark pairs for constructing fractal sets of large dimension that avoid a prescribed configuration is developed. This framework is applied to give some new results; in particular, it is shown that if α is an angle such that cos α is algebraic, then there is a subset of Rn of Hausdorff dimension n/4 that does not contain the angle α. The landmark pair framework generalizes a previous result of Mathe for polynomials with rational coefficients.


In another work, it is established that any subset of Fq∞ of sufficiently large Fourier dimension will always contain a three-term arithmetic progression. This contrasts with a real-variable construction of Shmerkin showing that subsets of R of Fourier dimension 1 need not contain three-term arithmetic progressions.


In a joint work with Wheeler, it is shown under certain circumstances that the set of numbers of exact approximation order introduced by Bugeaud has positive Fourier dimension. In particular, if ψ(q) is a decreasing function such that q2ψ(q) is nonincreasing and the upper and lower orders of ψ at infinity agree and are equal to τ > 1/2 (3 + √5) , then the set of numbers approximable to the exact order ψ has positive Fourier dimension.


Broader Impacts


As part of my NSF postdoctoral fellowship, I supervised two undergraduate projects. One of these projects was a University of Edinburgh Vacation Scholarship Project about the prime number theorem with student Yui Hang "Hanson" Lee. Hanson read through a few sources on the prime number theorem and wrote a summary of the proof. This reading project was performed entirely remotely because of the COVID-19 pandemic. My role was to direct Hanson's reading and discuss each chapter with him to make sure he understood the material. Hanson wrote a report entitled Riemann Zeta Function: the Prime Number Theorem and Explicit Formula summarizing the reading.


The second project I supervised was an informal summer research project with undergraduate student Sofiya Yatsyna. Sofiya read through some of the literature on large sets avoiding configurations. We then searched for examples that would fit the landmark framework.


I also involved Ph.D. student Reuben Wheeler in my research. Together, we proved a Fourier dimension estimate on sets of exact-order approximation. This introduced Reuben to Diophantine approximation, thereby broadening his research profile.
